newsitem.title: USA: US corp bonds off, Stratosphere rides rollercoaster.
newsitem.headline: US corp bonds off, Stratosphere rides rollercoaster.

text.p: U.S. corporate bonds closed significantly lower while the debt of casino and rollercoaster operator Stratosphere went for a wild ride only to end Wednesday's session unchanged, dealers said.

Stratosphere's 14.25 percent first mortgage notes shot up to an 87 bid from 81 at the open after the company announced it hired investment firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette (DLJ) as advisor in a bid to maximize shareholder value.
But the debt gradually pared gains to close unchanged.
"It went up because of the news and down after people said 'So what?'," one high-yield dealer said.
Some dealers said the firm's announcement was old news.
Merrill Lynch high-yield research said it was first disclosed on August 16 that the independent directors of Stratosphere had appointed DLJ to negotiate on behalf of the company.
Another key gainer was Kmart Corp debt, which rose 1/2 to one point, depending on maturity, on news earnings improved in the second quarter compared to the same period last year.
Kmart's 7.95 percent debentures due 2023 gained one point to close at a 73-1/2 bid.
The retailer said earnings in its second quarter ended July 31 rose to $0.07, matching retail analyts' expectations.
Kmart earned $0.05 per share in the quarter last year.

ValuJet Inc's 10.25 percent notes dropped about 1/2 point in light trading following news it will not receive federal approval to resume flight service by Friday as planned. The notes closed at 84 bid, 84-1/2 offer compared 84-1/2 bid, 85-1/4 offer late Tuesday.
Sprint Spectrum's $523 million (proceeds) zero-coupon/cash pay deal, which priced on Tuesday, bucked the overall soft market to end slightly higher, dealers said.

The first tranche of $250 million in 10-year senior notes traded ended 100-7/8 bid, 101-1/8 offer market, traders said. The notes were priced at par with an 11 percent coupon, and were quoted at 101-1/4 bid, 102 offer late Tuesday.

The second tranche of $273 million (proceeds) of 10-year senior discount notes, priced with a five-year zero coupon, also traded up to 55.375 bid, 55.625 offer. The notes were originally priced at 54.687 to yield 12.50 percent and rose to a 54.875 bid, 55.000 offer by Tuesday's close.
The entire issue is rated B2/B-plus.
Junk bonds overall closed off 1/8 as falling Treasuries and a weak equity market depressed prices.
The benchmark 30-year long bond closed down 15/32 to 98-29/32 to yield 6.84 percent in late trade. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed off 31.44 at 5689.82.
Only one new issue priced today. The Province of British Columbia issued a $300 million 40-year Yankee bond, said lead manager Lehman Brothers.
The AA2/AA+ issue priced at 99.225 to yield 7.31 percent or 44 basis points over the 6.0 percent Treasury due 2026.
--Roanne Daniels, 212-859-1677
